I’ve just wrapped up my first year of hard toil and dirty labour. Everything’s great, but I’ve got a few sanctimonies to share. Pierre is [spoiler]a real see you next Tuesday[/spoiler]. Do you know who can’t take Wednesdays off? Farmers. I never thought I’d side with big groceries, but JojaMart is looking better every day because of that pretentious little son of a gun!

Everyone needs to get back to work. The shop opening hours around here are akin to those in northern Britain—barely open, and when they are, there’s often nobody even tending the till! I’m up at the crack of dawn ready to crop and slay, but these slackers are clocking off to go to events. Another thing, Pam needs to quit drinking, but she’s very much a Midwestern gal so +1 for realism. As for the grump on wheels? Don’t even get me started.

I survived the first spring and summer selling coffee. I was disappointed to miss the Egg Festival, I felt like I’d let the community down. I’m ready for my second year. I’ve got all my crops planned out, sort of, and I’m going to bring every fishing trophy home! Pierre [spoiler]can get wrecked[/spoiler].

[b]What a game this is.[/b] if you're looking for something super casual and relaxing, this is it. As you can see, when I was writing this review I only have about 12 hours into the game on Steam, but I've been playing it for hours on mobile and now I've decided to buy it on Steam. This game is just perfect for unwinding and forgetting about everything else. It's the perfect stress relief when life gets overwhelming. 

First off, I really love the art design. The whole aesthetic is super cozy and unique, with it's charming pixel art style. It feels warm and nostalgic. The way the seasons change and how your farm evolves with them is really cool. Overall it's a vibe.

The soundtrack is nice, fitting the game's laid-back vibe perfectly. Can't say much about it. But I pretty much prefer throwing on my own playlist from Spotify while playing, nothing against it just a personal thing.

For real though, this game got me thinking "I want to retire and become a farmer." Just a peaceful life of farming and raising animals, living the dream out in the countryside. It's a slow paced game that gives you that peaceful "escape from it all" kind of vibe.

Out of all the activities you could do in this game, fishing is hands down the best for me. I can spend hours just fishing and getting that bread while my crops are growing. There's something about it that's just super satisfying. Best feature in the game lowkey. As for other activities like mining and combat, I think they are okay. Not my most favorite thing to do but I like that it's there for variety of things to do other than farming and fishing. I enjoyed getting to know the townspeople. Building relationships with them, and learning their stories adds some nice depth to the game. Giving them gifts and seeing their reactions makes the world feel more alive.

The way the game handles the changing seasons is cool. It's like real life, some crops only grow in certain seasons and there are fun little town events you can participate as the year goes by. The progression feels really balanced. There's always something to do, but It never feels like you're in a rush to get it done. I like that a lot, it keeps me engaged but still feels chill.

The amount of replayability in this game is pretty much endless. You can start a new game with different types of farms, which adds to the replayability. There are seven different farm types to choose from: standard, riverland, forest, hilltop, wilderness, four corners, and beach. Each farm has its own advantages and disadvantages, so you can really mix things up depending on your playstyle. I could imagine myself spending hundreds of hours and having many saves just trying out different farm layouts and farm types. 

Stardew Valley is the perfect game if you want to just relax and enjoy yourself while listening to that lo-fi playlist. This game is something that I would play after hours of studying, just to sit back, relax and let go of all that academic stress. It's a peaceful escape into a simple life where you can farm, fish, make friends, and take things at your own pace. If your looking for a casual relaxing game then this one is worth every penny. I highly recommend it and I think the other 652,236 overwhelmingly positive reviews would agree with me.

Oh yeah I also want to mention that the fact that this game is created by [b]ONE MAN[/b] is crazy. This man who goes by the name ConcernedApe is [b]HIM.[/b] He definitely cooked with this one. He has inspired me to learn coding myself and someday design my own game. Goat game developer, none of that corporate AAA game bullsh*t that offers no more other than microtransactions rather than giving a game that people truly enjoys. You can tell by playing this game that this developer is very passionate about his game and put actual effort on making the game. [b]ABSOLUTE CINEMA.[/b]

I have over 200 hours on this game across platforms. Incredibly relaxing, immersive, and addictive. I love the characters, I love the plotlines, I love the music. Stardew Valley is also extremely mod-friendly, which is great for me because I very much enjoy mods and currently have over 250 installed (although most of them just add more cosmetics). Highly highly recommend Stardew.

I didn't grow up playing this game, but came into it later in life. So, I'm not as charmed by the nostalgia beyond the name being popular. 

This game offers the relaxing steady pace gameplay that keeps me coming back. The game can get as, "crazy" as you want, diving head-long into the in-depth creative expression with your farm layout and produce. Alternatively, the game can be as, "chill" as you could ever wish for, beyond the steady crop/animal growth cycles and the march of the seasons. 

I would recommend this game to anyone in almost any age range if you enjoy video games, management, exploration, or building relationships with a diverse cast of characters.

Where do I begin with this Masterpiece? This game will have you hooked from the moment you start planting your first Parsnip (given this is your type of game), its a game that can make or break you. This is my 2nd time picking this game up and after gaining all the EXTENSIVE knowledge there is to this game, I can say that everything about it is perfect. My favorite thing about this game is that I hate grinding games, but love how unique farming in this game is and the cut scenes, the character stories and relationships, the hidden secrets around the valley, and the ability to raise animals and build your farm from a tile up. It made it to where I felt like I wasn't just grinding, there was always something new going on. While it does tend to seem like a lot at first, its really easy and paced really well to where if you do it correctly you should be complete the basics within one year. If you wanted to dive deeper then you should be done within year 3-4. I  recommend the Stardew Wiki as well to help you learn a lot!  10/10 game, and also bonus points for it being made by a single person, which I always love. All the work that went into this game was definitely appreciated on my end.

Considered one of the best farming simulators, Stardew Valley is polished to near perfection for what it was designed to do. The game is a sandbox for farming, animal husbandry, some hack and slash rpg and even a dating simulator. The game has been out for quite some time and it evolved significantly since its inception. Between plating and milking cows the player can explore the dungeons filled with monsters and gems or stroll the town befriending anyone and searching for a soulmate amongst the multiple options available. The game deserves all the gaming praise it already has. Overall Stardew valley is a very relaxing game. Unless you want to challenge yourself to get all the achievements, then it is one of the most stressful games available. The reason for such an effect is the random number generation that permeates everything. The chance to find a geode that grants you a slim chance to find the specific mineral or artifact you want, the slim chance to find the correct skull while digging or dungeoneering. The slim chance of getting the correct seed from the traveling cart. The randomness is in everything. That is not something bad in itself, but when you consider the vast amount of items you need for the achievements, it is very frustrating to open one hundred geodes or farming golden coconuts. The game is also known for its modding community. One quick look at any catalog will show you thousands of mods for almost anything you desire. I tried some basic ones and could see improvements for time management, but be on alert, if you want to get all the achievements, pay attention to mods that add new items, quests, and content that can interfere with the basic ones. You will have to get those items as well in order to complete the achievements, changing an already arduous task into something herculean.  On the subject of mods and overall techniques, the game is shockingly impervious to bugs. Either because of its simplicity or because of polishness, Stardew Valley never faltered or wavered, proving it to be incredibly steady and technically solid. The worst of it is a slight framerate drop if you add dozens of mods, but that is not the game's code fault. You can even add and remove mods freely without crashes or save file corruption, as long as you have the basic structural mods for mods. My biggest gripe with Stardew Valley, besides the aforementioned randomness, is the addition of Ginger Island. During update 1.5 a new location was added with its own mechanics, quests, and items. Additional content is always welcome, but for some reason this island has a very unique intractability. You need to find a resource that is scattered throughout the island, a resource that is not only limited in its total amount , but also limited by the form of acquiring it, being required at bulk to unlock the content of the expansion. I have never seen something alike. Without a very detailed guide, it was one of the most infuriating experiences I've had in gaming. Not only that, the island is now necessary for achievements. So for a complete run, you are forced to go through this completely different part of the game. The island is not the problem, but how you navigate in it is a massive negative mark in this almost flawless game. Stardew Valley is easily a recommendable game that every farming enjoyer should play, but completionists beware, this one can be quite a hussle.

As a long time skeptic of whether or not I would like this game, I am pleasantly surprised. It took about an hour of playing before it 'clicked' for me in game. 

Stardew Valley is very relaxing in a way most other games I play are not. There is very little expected of me as the player. You can take on as much or little as you'd like, mostly in the form of tasks/quests posted to the community bulletin board. It seems like, at least early on, you can kind of ignore certain aspects of the game if you don't want to do them (ie. if you hate fishing, you don't *need* to do it to have a successful farm, or to explore the mines). 

If I had 1-2 gripes early on, its that the music feels a bit repetitive, and there isn't enough time on an in-game day to do everything I want to do... which probably lends itself to being a compliment about how much you *can* do in a day in this game.

[h1]Review: Stardew Valley[/h1]

⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️ (5/5)

72 hours later, and I’m still hooked on Stardew Valley! What starts as a simple farming game turns into a huge adventure filled with farming, friendships, exploration, and a bit of dungeon-crawling. Every in-game day pulls you deeper into its relaxing but addictive rhythm.

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️ (5/5)
It’s incredibly satisfying to see your farm grow over time. Whether you’re planting crops, raising animals, or upgrading your house, every bit of progress feels rewarding. On top of that, there’s fishing, mining, and even combat in the caves, so you’re never stuck doing just one thing.

[h2]Graphics & Design[/h2]
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️ (4/5)
The pixel art style is simple but beautiful. Each season looks distinct, and the colorful visuals are part of what makes the game feel so cozy. It’s not high-end graphics, but that’s not the point—the charm and atmosphere come through perfectly.

[h2]Story & Characters[/h2]
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️ (5/5)
The residents of Pelican Town are surprisingly complex. I’ve spent hours just trying to build relationships with them, learning their backstories and events. It’s heartwarming to see how they react to your gifts and progress. There are also little storylines—like the tension between Joja Corporation and the town—that make you feel more connected to the world.

[h2]Replayability[/h2]
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️ (4/5)
Even after 72 hours, I still feel like I’ve barely scratched the surface. I keep finding new ways to improve my farm or explore hidden areas. The variety of tasks ensures no two playthroughs feel exactly the same, and multiplayer adds even more value if you want to share the experience with friends.

[h2]Pacing[/h2]
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️ (4/5)
It’s the perfect game to play at your own speed. Some days I focus on farming, while other days I dive into the mines or just walk around talking to NPCs. There’s no pressure, just a relaxing flow—though you might find yourself saying, “Just one more day...” for hours.

Stardew Valley: A Charming Escape into Rural Bliss

Stardew Valley is more than just a farming simulation game—it’s a heartfelt journey into a peaceful rural life. Whether you're tending to crops, raising animals, mining for rare gems, or building friendships with the town’s quirky residents, Stardew Valley offers a wholesome, immersive experience that captivates from the very start.

The beauty of the game lies in its simplicity. At its core, Stardew Valley revolves around transforming a run-down farm into a thriving homestead. But it quickly becomes clear that the game offers so much more than planting crops and harvesting. There’s an entire town to explore, complete with festivals, secret locations, and rich backstories. Every villager has a unique personality, and building relationships with them feels rewarding as you learn their stories, struggles, and joys. Whether you're cooking meals, crafting items, or solving mysteries, the game constantly gives you new tasks without overwhelming you.

The pixel art style adds to the charm, blending retro visuals with modern design sensibilities. The seasons change in beautifully subtle ways, and every day feels different. The soundtrack is equally mesmerizing, with peaceful melodies that enhance the calming nature of the game. It’s easy to lose track of time in Stardew Valley—the hours melt away as you engage in its many fulfilling tasks.

What sets Stardew Valley apart is its freedom. You can focus on farming, delve into the mines for resources, or fish by the riverside all day. There’s no rush, no strict deadlines—just a world that lets you set your own pace. This freedom, combined with the rewarding progression system, ensures that no two players will have the same experience.

Multiplayer mode adds another layer of fun. You can share your farm with friends, collaborate on projects, and enjoy the game’s tranquil atmosphere together.

In summary, Stardew Valley is a game that celebrates the beauty of simplicity and the joy of discovery. It’s perfect for anyone seeking an escape from the stresses of everyday life, offering a tranquil, heartwarming experience that lingers long after you’ve put the game down.

Rating: 9.5/10

Amazing.  Recently got the perfection achievement, mostly to get before this madlad solo dev that makes another great update that makes getting the achievement take more work, but it would be a lie for me to say it was anything but enjoyable if that was the case. 

Any downsides?  Maybe that the end game grind take some work and rules out some of the preconfigured farms.  There is simply no way to get the 15+ million gold you need to unlock everything with some farms that have less land you can cultivate.  It took me a long time to complete the crafting goal only to find out there is an UI option to see how many each have been crafted.  But also many craftable items require a blueprint acquired through the extended village jobs that rotate, so if you don't get one you need you have to wait another 7 in game days to get the job you need.  But even then they provide a useful resource when you complete them.  Hardly a deterrent.

All this content, wonderful experiences, for 15 bucks?!?  A great work

As someone who grew up playing Harvest Moon, when I first saw this game I just brushed it off as a rip-off, but I was so wrong. This game takes the farming/life simulator formula that Harvest Moon basically created and expands on it in very meaningful and important ways offering more QOL and Role-play than Harvest Moon or even Story of Seasons currently offer in their games. The base game is extremely fun and addicting and their are numerous mods that make it even more fun and add cool stuff to the game, but mods never feel necessary for this game. The environments and seasons look amazing,  the characters are very well-written and believable, and the game never feels too grindy.

Honestly, in my view, [b]Stardew Valley[/b] is more for a niche audience, especially those who appreciate old-school charm. I played it just to tick it off my gaming experience list, and because of its fascinating development story, which was covered by [i]Jason Schreier[/i] and which you might not know. 

[i]Eric Barone[/i] lived off his girlfriend’s income while they struggled to make ends meet, renting a modest house with friends, all while his family doubted the project’s success. Yet, through four years of determination, he taught himself everything from coding to art and music, creating what became an indie sensation and a modern tribute to [i]Harvest Moon[/i]. His dedication resulted in a game that has since captivated players around the world.

After [b]Stardew Valley[/b] gained popularity, Eric Barone, the game's creator, had the opportunity to meet [i]Yasuhiro Wada[/i], the original creator of the [i]Harvest Moon[/i] series. This meeting was significant, as Wada had been an inspiration for Barone during his development of [b]Stardew Valley[/b]. When they met, Wada expressed admiration for Barone's work and how he had successfully revitalized the farming sim genre. This encounter was a touching moment for Barone, as it felt like a full-circle experience—his childhood inspiration acknowledging his hard work and success.

I like such kind of stories. Such cases are crucial for understanding gaming, the nuances of the industry, and the involvement of individual creators and their dedication. They highlight how personal sacrifices and passion for beloved games can drive innovation and inspire future generations of developers

As a mental result, [b]Stardew Valley[/b] is the only game where you can leave your soul-crushing corporate job to find inner peace by... growing parsnips. It’s part farming, part small-town gossip simulator, where your toughest decision is whether to plant cauliflower or finally talk to the brooding guy at the saloon.

I feel my time hasn’t come yet to fall in love with this game, and I believe, that time will come one day.  

For me and for now, it's more about the story of the game than the game itself.

Why am I even writing this review? Who the hell knows you should know this game is great already. In case you live under a rock or were born 32 seconds ago though lets get into it. 
Stardew Valley is perhaps one of the best games in my library. Its simplistic art style will pull you in and you cant get out. With tons of hours of gameplay and endless replay-ability this game is one of the best in the genre. There are so many things you can do and you can play differently each save. With tons of customization options you can do anything. Build the home of your dreams or the trailer in your nightmares. Create yourself, recreate a fictional character, or immerse yourself with your own in depth character with deep backstory. With tons of mods available this game never runs out of content to enjoy. 10/10 would buy 20 times over.

This is a lovely game with a lot of time, effort and energy put in to it. I love how it is cozy, but you also get to interact with other characters, build skills, etc throughout the game. While it is not a stress free game all the time (RIP me in the mines), I do use it to unwind. Each day plays for about 20 minutes but it certainly feels like it goes by much quicker. Easy to binge. The only thing I wish the game could do is transfer data from playing on other platforms (for me, it would be on my phone since I travel often and it can be played without internet) so you don't lose progress or are able to play other story lines. Other than that, I was very happy to have this be the first video game I purchased to play via STEAM.

It is thanks to this game that I decided to take a chance on the Steam Deck so I could experience that mod on the go. And for that simple fact, I am thankful. Stardew Valley has earned its reputation as one of the best games ever through a remarkable blend of farming simulation, role-playing elements, and rich community engagement that captivates players of all ages. At its core, the game invites players to step into the shoes of a character who inherits a neglected farm from their grandfather. This simple premise blossoms into a multifaceted experience that encourages exploration, creativity, and personal growth, setting the stage for countless adventures.

One of the most captivating features of Stardew Valley is its beautifully crafted pixel art style, which creates a warm and inviting atmosphere. Each season brings vibrant changes to the environment, with spring bursting into bloom, summer offering sun-soaked days, autumn displaying a tapestry of colors, and winter blanketing the landscape in serene white. These seasonal shifts not only enhance the visual appeal but also introduce new crops, animals, and activities, making the passage of time feel significant and engaging. Players must strategize around the changing seasons, planning their farming activities to maximize yields and prepare for the next cycle.

The heart of Stardew Valley lies in its rich tapestry of characters, each with unique personalities, backgrounds, and stories. Players can build relationships with a diverse cast of non-player characters (NPCs), from the shy introvert to the boisterous local blacksmith. Each character has their own routines, likes, and dislikes, adding depth to interactions and encouraging players to invest time in understanding them. As players befriend these characters, they unlock special events, heartwarming cutscenes, and even romance options, creating a sense of emotional connection that elevates the gameplay experience. The joy of developing friendships and witnessing the characters grow over time makes the world feel alive and immersive.

Beyond farming and relationships, Stardew Valley offers a multitude of engaging activities that keep the gameplay fresh and dynamic. Players can delve into fishing, which requires skill and patience, or embark on mining expeditions to uncover valuable resources and combat various creatures lurking in the depths. The crafting system adds another layer of complexity, enabling players to create tools, machines, and artisan goods that enhance their farming operations and provide additional income. This variety of activities ensures that players can tailor their experiences to their preferences, whether they enjoy the hustle and bustle of farming, the thrill of exploration, or the satisfaction of crafting.

The game also emphasizes themes of sustainability and community. As players work to restore their farm and contribute to the local economy, they engage in a narrative that mirrors real-world values of cooperation, environmental stewardship, and resilience. Players can participate in seasonal festivals, support local businesses, and even help fellow villagers with their challenges, fostering a sense of belonging and interconnectedness. This aspect of the game encourages players to reflect on their own lives, their relationships with others, and their impact on the community.

Moreover, Stardew Valley encourages creativity through its open-ended nature. Players have the freedom to design their farms according to their vision, whether they prefer a sprawling agricultural empire or a quaint, cozy homestead. This customization fosters a sense of ownership and pride, as players can see the tangible results of their efforts. The game’s soothing soundtrack, combined with its charming visuals, creates an immersive experience that invites players to lose themselves in the rhythm of rural life.

The developer, ConcernedApe, has also demonstrated a commitment to continuously improving the game through updates and expansions, adding new features, content, and quality-of-life improvements that keep the community engaged. This dedication further solidifies Stardew Valley’s status as a beloved title, as it evolves and adapts to meet the desires of its players.

In conclusion, Stardew Valley transcends the boundaries of traditional gaming, creating a holistic experience that combines engaging gameplay, heartfelt storytelling, and a strong sense of community. Its enchanting art style, rich character interactions, and diverse activities come together to offer a sanctuary where players can escape the fast-paced nature of modern life. As players cultivate their farms, build relationships, and explore the world, they embark on a journey of creativity, mindfulness, and connection, solidifying Stardew Valley’s place as not just a game, but a timeless experience that resonates deeply with all who play it. This unique combination of elements makes Stardew Valley a truly unforgettable game, deserving of its title as one of the best games of all time.

Just kinda meh. I don't regret picking it up, but it's just not that good. Doesn't do much to improve on the games it was inspired by, they just didn't exist on PC before this game reminded every-developer-forever that you can make money with 'New Guy/Gal in Town' games.  With just a single dev, updates are few and far between. Will likely be outdone by other games, if it hasn't been already. 

There aren't many ways to modify anything meaningful when starting a file. Selecting the type of farm you have throughout the game is the most meaningful option. You can 'force year one completion', but you need to make sure that you're checking the time-sensitive vendor every time it's available or you're just out of luck for that year.  

Days go by too quickly. This is a much bigger problem in multiplayer due to time not stopping in menus or during cutscenes. Kinda ruins the whole 'laid-back' feel I would expect from a game like this. The core loop is very very basic, and nothing really changes even after unlocks. Grow things, sell them. Sometimes you age them for a period of time but really it's just all the same. No crossbreeding, no genetics, no hybrid plants, just plant a seed, water it, and wait. I can understand not wanting to make farming that deep, but I was expecting the depth to show up in cooking recipes or raising animals.  

You can fish and raise animals, but again, a lot of the outputs are just things you throw in the box to sell.

Cooking is the biggest disappointment. I expected a lot more from a game like this, but there are really only a handful of useful recipes and everything else is just filler. Most of the best/useful recipes are locked behind leveling-up character relationships. This isn't really a problem... until you realize how bad the other recipes are.

Interactions with villagers are cute, but don't always have depth to them. In my experience it just boiled down to giving a liked item as often as possible to get a recipe as fast as possible. Characters are unique, have schedules ect, but there is no in-game way to track any of it. I don't really focus on this side of games like this, but the lack of QoL around the relationship part of the game is noticeable. 

Shops are also not available on certain days, which is just obnoxious. Doubly so when you waste hours running into town only to realize it's a Friday and the blacksmith isn't there.

I'm not a fan of the events because they take up the whole day. You CAN skip them, but it's really not a good idea at least for the first time going through a year. More seem to get added with every major update. I found them to be necessary and didn't like that I couldn't do whatever I had planned to do that day, but I'm probably in the minority.

Some aspects are very RNG heavy in a way that doesn't respect your time. There are a few important rare drops (prismatic shards are the biggest offender) with very low drop rates. If there wasn't a duplication glitch in multiplayer to help mitigate the time-sinks, I probably would have stopped playing. 

The combat sucks. Not the focus of the game, but it is important to progression. Everything is basically a sword with faster or slower swing speed. There are also very limited ranged options. There's a wizard in town... but you can't do magic. Need to keep that realism I guess. Turnips grow in four days though. 

10 years from now when the dev gets around to improving and expanding on the gameplay I'll probably like it more. Mods probably make the game much more enjoyable, but they aren't through the workshop so I haven't bothered.

The perfect balance of short-term gratification building up to long-term gratification. There is a learning curve but nothing too complicated. The beginning hours of your gameplay will likely be you feeling like you just have no time/energy to do anything except clearing your farm and setting crops. But once you get past that and start putting down sprinklers, you're going to find you have quite a bit of time to explore the mines and/or explore the relationships with each NPC in town. The crops you grow can also be used to create artisan items such as wine, jam, pickled veggies, etc etc to sell for even more money. The animal products you get can also be made into more expensive items to sell as well!

I only have 105 hours on Steam, but on my Switch I have at least double this. The replay-ability of this game is a 10/10 because you can begin experimenting with efficiency if that's your jam.

It's definitely worth $15.
